{{Unreferenced|date=March 2007}} A '''dockominium''' is the water-based version of a [[condominium]]; rather than owning an apartment in a building, one owns a [[Slipway|boat slip]] on the water. The term is a [[portmanteau]] of "dock" and "condominium." In addition to the exclusive right to use the boat slip, ownership also provides one with the right to use the common elements of the [[marina]], much the same as one would have the right to use the common areas in a residential condominium development. Also, unit owners may use, rent, or sell their unit at any time, subject to association approval.
==Dockominium==
Similar to a condominium, a management company manages the common areas and provides all required services such as maintenance, security, insurance, bookkeeping, legal, and overall management and supervision of the dockominium facility. A monthly fee is charged to cover these expenses. Typically, water is included, while electricity and cable, etc. are billed separately via the management association. [[Real estate]] taxes are separately assessed by the municipality and are the responsibility of the unit owner.
==Purpose==
A dockominium is created when a marina converts or sells individual slips to individual owners. Traditionally, marinas are in the business of renting or leasing space. A comparison would be the conversion of a rental apartment to a condominium. An association is created that monitors the maintenance and operation of the marina. Individual owners are responsible for paying their monthly, quarterly, or annual association dues and for paying their own [[property tax]]es assessed on the slip. Dockominium conversions are a popular trend taking place in the marina industry in high demand areas focusing on the luxury markets.
==Limits==
However, despite the advantages, whether or not dockominium sales are legal varies according to laws of each area. Few marina owners also own the land under the water, and most have only an easement to the property. Individual unit sales may violate law, thus following the legal concept of the [[public trust doctrine]] that provides that [[public trust]] lands, waters, and living resources in a state are held by the State in trust for the benefit of all of the people.
==See also== * [[Condominium]] * [[Marina]] * [[Real estate]]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110716231557/http://www.thedockominiumgroup.com/faqs.1.html Dockominium FAQs] from the [http://www.thedockominiumgroup.com/ Dockominium group]

The '''Dolev–Yao model'''<ref name="DolevYao">{{Citation | last1 = Dolev | first1 = D. | last2 = Yao | first2 = A. C. | title = On the security of public key protocols | journal = IEEE Transactions on Information Theory | volume = IT-29 | url = http://www.cs.huji.ac.il/~dolev/pubs/dolev-yao-ieee-01056650.pdf | pages = 198–208 | year = 1983 | doi = 10.1109/tit.1983.1056650 }}</ref> is a [[Mathematical model|formal model]] used to prove properties of interactive cryptographic protocols.<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Backes | first1 = Michael | last2 = Pfitzmann | first2 = Birgit | last3 = Waidner | first3 = Michael | title = Soundness Limits of Dolev-Yao Models | url = https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/08/06/78/PDF/paper6.pdf | series = Workshop on Formal and Computational Cryptography (FCC'06), affiliated with ICALP'06 | year = 2006 }}</ref><ref> {{Citation | last1 = Chen | first1 = Quingfeng | last2 = Zhang | first2 = Chengqi | last3 = Zhang | first3 = Shichao | title = Secure Transaction Protocol Analysis: Models and Applications | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=IMIuV_tUYfMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=secure+transaction+protocol+analysis+models+applications&source=bl&ots=7iqJoLjEmJ&sig=8SSMmTl8djd4St90QW6zlYPzcDA&hl=en&ei=OPMNTavHIIrmvQP1qLXLDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false | series = Lecture Notes in Computer Science / Programming and Software Engineering | year = 2008 }}</ref>
==The network==
The network is represented by a set of abstract machines that can exchange messages. These messages consist of formal terms. These terms reveal some of the internal structure of the messages, but some parts will hopefully remain opaque to the adversary.
==The adversary==
The adversary in this model can overhear, intercept, and synthesize any message and is only limited by the constraints of the cryptographic methods used. In other words: "the attacker carries the message."
This [[omnipotence]] has been very difficult to model and many threat models simplify it, as, for example, the attacker in [[ubiquitous computing]].
==The algebraic model==
[[Cryptographic primitive]]s are modeled by abstract operators. For example, asymmetric encryption for a user <math>x</math> is represented by the encryption function <math>E_x</math> and the decryption function <math>D_x</math>. Their main properties are that their composition is the [[identity function]] (<math>D_x E_x = E_x D_x = 1</math>) and that an encrypted message <math>E_x(M)</math> reveals nothing about <math>M</math>. Unlike in the real world, the adversary can neither manipulate the encryption's bit representation nor guess the key. The attacker may, however, re-use any messages that have been sent and therefore become known. The attacker can encrypt or decrypt these with any keys he knows, to forge subsequent messages.
A protocol is modeled as a set of sequential runs, alternating between queries (sending a message over the network) and responses (obtaining a message from the network).
===Remark===
The symbolic nature of the Dolev–Yao model makes it more manageable than computational models and accessible to [[algebra]]ic methods but potentially less realistic. However, both kinds of models for cryptographic protocols have been related.<ref name="Herzog">{{Citation | contribution = A Computational Interpretation of Dolev-Yao Adversaries | citeseerx = 10.1.1.94.2941 | last1 = Herzog | first1 = Jonathan | year = 2005 }}</ref> Also, symbolic models are very well suited to show that a protocol is ''broken'', rather than secure, under the given assumptions about the attackers capabilities.
==See also== * [[Security]] * [[Cryptographic protocol]]

[[File:Flago pri la Tago de Samrajta Pago en Alsbach (DE).JPG|thumb|Equal Pay Day flag flying on March 21, 2014 in [[Alsbach-Hähnlein|Alsbach]], Germany ]]'''Equal Pay Day''' is the symbolic day dedicated to raising awareness of the [[gender pay gap]]. The date for 2018 was April 10 in the United States.<ref>https://www.pay-equity.org/day.html</ref> This date symbolizes how far into the year women must work to earn what men earned in the previous year, the exact day differs both by year and by country.<ref name=":0" /> For example, Equal Pay Day in 2005 in the United States was on April 19.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pay-equity.org/day-kit-activities.html#2005|title=Equal Pay Day events|website=www.pay-equity.org|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref> In 2016, the average salary for females in the United States was 79% of that of the average male.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aauw.org/research/the-simple-truth-about-the-gender-pay-gap/|title=The Simple Truth about the Gender Pay Gap (Spring 2016)|website=AAUW: Empowering Women Since 1881|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref>
== Background ==
The symbolic day was first observed in 1996<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pay-equity.org/day.html|title=Equal Pay Day|website=www.pay-equity.org|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref> by the National Committee on Pay Equity, a coalition of women's and civil rights organizations, labor unions, professional associations and individuals working to eliminate sex and race based wage discrimination and to achieve pay equity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pay-equity.org/about.html|title=About the National Committee on Pay Equity|website=www.pay-equity.org|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref>
The [[gender pay gap]] is defined as the average difference between men’s and women’s aggregate hourly earnings. The wage gap is due to a variety of causes, such as differences in education choices, differences in preferred job and industry, differences in the types of positions held by men and women, differences in the type of jobs men typically go into as opposed to women (especially highly paid high risk jobs), differences in amount of work experience, difference in length of the work week, and breaks in employment. These factors resolve 60% to 75% of the pay gap, depending on the source. Various explanations for the remaining 25% to 40% have been suggested, including women's lower willingness and ability to negotiate salaries and discrimination.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2015/04/14/on-equal-pay-day-everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-gender-pay-gap/|title=On Equal Pay Day, key facts about the gender pay gap|website=Pew Research Center|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Blau|first=Francine D.|last2=Kahn|first2=Lawrence M.|date=2007-02-01|title=The Gender Pay Gap Have Women Gone as Far as They Can?|url=http://amp.aom.org/content/21/1/7|journal=Academy of Management Perspectives|language=en|volume=21|issue=1|pages=7–23|doi=10.5465/AMP.2007.24286161|issn=1558-9080}}</ref> According to the [[European Commission]] direct discrimination either does not cause any gender wage differences or only explains a small part of it.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/justice/gender-equality/gender-pay-gap/causes/index_en.htm|title=What are the causes? - European Commission|website=ec.europa.eu|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref>
== Observance in other countries ==
=== Germany === Equal pay day is more widely observed in Germany than it is in the United States, or elsewhere for that matter; for example, the online presence is far greater, such as the [http://www.equalpay.wiki/Hauptseite Equal Pay Day Wiki], the [[:de:Equal Pay Day|Equal Pay Day]] Wikipedia page in German, and this [http://www.equalpayday.de/startseite/ Equal Pay Day] informational site (all links are in German). An interesting thing to note about Equal Pay Day in Germany is that it falls on different days than it does in the United States, because the wage gap in Germany is different and also because the formula used to calculate the Equal Pay Day date is different. Whereas in 2016 Equal Pay Date in the United States was observed on April 12, in Germany it was observed on March 19.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.equalpayday.de/startseite/|title=Startseite|website=www.equalpayday.de|access-date=2016-04-26}}</ref>
=== Other countries === The date on which Equal Pay Day is observed is different in every country due to differing formulas for observing the day and also due to different wage gaps. For example Equal Pay Day in Czech Republic is observed each year as a major two-day event involving over 2,000 people with an extensive educational program. See more on http://www.equalpayday.cz.
== See also == * [[Equal pay for equal work]] * [[Gender pay gap in the United States]] * [[Glass ceiling]]

[[Katter's Australian Party|Katter's Australian]] (2018) | spouse = Fiona Anning | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Queensland Gatton Campus|University of Queensland, Gatton Campus]] | residence = [[Gladstone, Queensland]], [[Australia]] | occupation = [[Hotelier|Hotel owner]]

[[Politician]] | allegiance = [[Australia|Commonweath of Australia]] | branch = [[Australian Army Reserve]] | serviceyears = 1969–1973{{ref|https://www.aph.gov.au/Senators_and_Members/Parliamentarian?MPID=273829}} | unit = [[49th Battalion (Australia)|49th Battalion]], [[Royal Queensland Regiment]] }} '''William Fraser Anning''' (born 14 October 1949) is an Australian politician who has been a [[Australian Senate|Senator]] for [[Queensland]] since 10 November 2017.{{cite news|last1=Remeikis|first1=Amy|title=One Nation's next-in-line senator mired in legal proceedings since April 2016|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/sep/28/one-nations-next-in-line-senator-mired-in-legal-proceedings-since-april-2016|accessdate=10 November 2017|work=The Guardian|date=27 September 2017|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171110114808/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/sep/28/one-nations-next-in-line-senator-mired-in-legal-proceedings-since-april-2016 |archivedate=10 November 2017|df=}} He was elected to the Senate after a special recount was triggered by the removal of [[One Nation Party|One Nation]] senator [[Malcolm Roberts (politician)|Malcolm Roberts]], who was found ineligible to be chosen as a senator due to [[2017 Australian parliamentary eligibility crisis|his citizenship status]]. He chose not to join One Nation in the Senate, sitting as an independent until June 2018 when he joined [[Katter's Australian Party]] as its first senator, before later being expelled from the party in October 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-10-25/fraser-anning-dumped-from-katters-australian-party/10428482|title=Fraser Anning dumped from Katter's Australian Party for views on race, non-European migration|last=Doran|first=Matthew|date=25 October 2018|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|access-date=25 October 2018|last2=Belot|first2=Henry|language=en-AU|last3=Probyn|first3=Andrew|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181025075332/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-10-25/fraser-anning-dumped-from-katters-australian-party/10428482|archive-date=2018-10-25|dead-url=no|df=}} ==Personal life and family history== Anning and his wife own a number of hotels and live in [[Gladstone, Queensland|Gladstone]]. They have two daughters.{{cite web |title=Fraser Anning: MP’s full speech on Muslim immigration ban |url=https://www.news.com.au/national/politics/fraser-anning-mps-full-speech-on-muslim-immigration-ban/news-story/1bffbc6235fe91172209eff86c8a7aa9 |website=news.com.au |accessdate=4 November 2018 |date=15 August 2018}} Anning grew up in north-west Queensland on Wetherby Station, one of the Anning family's pastoral properties near the isolated town of [[Richmond, Queensland|Richmond]]. Anning is the great grandson of Charles Cumming Stone Anning, a British [[squatting (pastoral)|pastoral squatter]] who came to the Australian colonies in the mid 19th century to acquire landholdings. In 1862, Charles and several of his adult sons established the Reedy Springs property north of [[Hughenden, Queensland|Hughenden]]. The family soon expanded their claims by forming the nearby properties of Chudleigh Park, Mount Sturgeon, Charlotte Plains and Cargoon.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63080682 |title=ANROUD THE CAMPFIRE |newspaper=[[Townsville Daily Bulletin]] |volume=LXIX |location=Queensland, Australia |date=16 November 1949 |accessdate=14 November 2018 |page=7 |via=National Library of Australia}} All this land was occupied at the time by various Aboriginal clans and subsequent [[Australian frontier wars|frontier conflict]] occurred as the Annings forcibly took control of the land from the local people. In response to the spearing of cattle, Charles and his sons would ride out with firearms, attack Aboriginal campsites and capture young boys who survived in order to use them as labour on their cattle and sheep stations.{{cite book |last1=Loos |first1=Noel |title=Invasion and Resistance |date=2017 |publisher=Boolarong Press |location=Salisbury |pages=44, 57 |edition=2nd}} In 1865, the Annings employed W.R.O. Hill, an officer in the paramilitary [[Native Police]], to be their station manager at Reedy Springs. Hill, who had experience in warfare against Aboriginal people, wrote in his memoirs that at Reedy Springs the "only wise thing to do on seeing a black was to shoot and shoot straight".{{cite book |last1=Hill |first1=W.R.O. |title=Forty-five years' experience in North Queensland |date=1907 |publisher=H.Pole & Co. |location=Brisbane |pages=29-31 |url=http://www.textqueensland.com.au/item/book/4a265427ff1b47c4f085c2c4fbe519d3}} [[Frank Hann]], who was another pastoralist in the region who regularly participated in extrajudicial punitive raids on Aboriginals, described in his diary in 1874 how he saw "Anning just come back from hunting blacks."{{cite web |last1=Babidge |first1=Sally |title=Family Affairs: an historical anthropology of state practice and Aboriginal agency in a rural town, North Queensland |url=https://researchonline.jcu.edu.au/942/2/02whole.pdf |accessdate=14 November 2018}} Fraser Anning's grandfather, Francis "Frank" Albert Anning, spent much of his time at Reedy Springs but also bought into further properties such as Wollogorang, Savannah Station and Compton Downs. At Wollogorang in particular, Frank Anning had to surround his hut with wire mesh to prevent spear attacks and was knocked unconscious by a [[waddy]] in another incident. One of Frank's sons was W.H.(Harry) Anning who took up the Wetherby property,{{cite web |last1=Stafford |first1=Megan |title=Qld cattle pioneer chronicled |url=https://www.northqueenslandregister.com.au/story/3579350/qld-cattle-pioneer-chronicled/ |website=North Queensland Register |accessdate=14 November 2018}} and whose wife gave birth to Fraser Anning in October 1949.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49713021 |title=Family Notices |newspaper=[[The Courier-mail]] |issue=4023 |location=Queensland, Australia |date=18 October 1949 |accessdate=14 November 2018 |page=12 |via=National Library of Australia}} ==Political career== In 1998, he stood as a One Nation candidate for the lower house [[division of Fairfax]] at [[Australian federal election, 1998|that year's federal election]].{{cite news|title=Who is Fraser Anning: Queensland publican takes Malcolm Roberts' Senate spot|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-11-07/one-nation-fraser-anning-replaces-senator-malcolm-roberts/9121812|accessdate=10 November 2017|work=ABC News|date=7 November 2017|language=en-AU|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171110065508/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-11-07/one-nation-fraser-anning-replaces-senator-malcolm-roberts/9121812|archivedate=10 November 2017|df=}} Anning was third on the One Nation ticket in Queensland at the [[Australian federal election, 2016|2016 federal election]]. He gained just 19 first-preference votes under the [[optional preferential voting]] system to select twelve senators from Queensland.{{cite news |title=Fraser Anning got just 19 votes last year. He could be Australia's next senator |url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/fraser-anning-got-just-19-votes-last-year-he-could-be-australias-next-senator-20170926-gyoxxw.html |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |first=Adam |last=Gartrell |accessdate=15 August 2018 |date=26 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180815131427/https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/fraser-anning-got-just-19-votes-last-year-he-could-be-australias-next-senator-20170926-gyoxxw.html |archive-date=2018-08-15 |dead-url=no |df= }} Prior to his appointment to the Senate, he was facing bankruptcy legal action due to money owed to the [[Bendigo and Adelaide Bank]] which could have made him ineligible, but the case was withdrawn. Upon his swearing in to the Senate on 13 November 2017, Anning was vouched for (a parliamentary custom indicating that the new member is who he claims to be{{Cite web |url=https://www.aph.gov.au/~/media/05%20About%20Parliament/52%20Sen/524%20Research%20and%20education/Other%20Publications/swearing-in_annemieke_jongsma.pdf?la=en |title={title} |access-date=2018-08-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180818115320/https://www.aph.gov.au/~/media/05%20About%20Parliament/52%20Sen/524%20Research%20and%20education/Other%20Publications/swearing-in_annemieke_jongsma.pdf?la=en |archive-date=2018-08-18 |dead-url=no |df= }}) by two crossbenchers from other parties: [[Cory Bernardi]] ([[Australian Conservatives]]) and [[David Leyonhjelm]] ([[Liberal Democratic Party (Australia)|Liberal Democrats]]).{{Cite web |url=https://www.popsugar.com.au/news/Pauline-Hanson-One-Nation-Senator-Quits-44252187 |title={title} |access-date=2018-08-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180818115412/https://www.popsugar.com.au/news/Pauline-Hanson-One-Nation-Senator-Quits-44252187 |archive-date=2018-08-18 |dead-url=no |df= }} One Nation leader [[Pauline Hanson]] subsequently issued a media release saying that Anning had "abandoned" the party to sit as an independent "until something else comes along".{{cite news|title=Hanson says newest senator Fraser Anning has abandoned One Nation |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-11-13/hanson-says-anning-has-abandoned-one-nation/9144142|accessdate=13 November 2017|work=ABC News|date=13 November 2017|language=en-AU|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171113005913/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-11-13/hanson-says-anning-has-abandoned-one-nation/9144142|archivedate=13 November 2017|df=}} Anning responded that "she [Hanson] made my position pretty much untenable with her conditions."{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/she-made-the-decision-inside-the-shock-collapse-of-one-nations-senate-bloc-20171113-gzkbw5.html|title='She made the decision': Inside the shock collapse of One Nation's Senate bloc|first=Adam|last=Gartrell|date=13 November 2017|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2017|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114054744/http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/she-made-the-decision-inside-the-shock-collapse-of-one-nations-senate-bloc-20171113-gzkbw5.html|archivedate=14 November 2017|df=}} On 16 November, it was reported that neither Anning nor Hanson had formally made their intentions clear to the Senate chamber regarding his party status, and he therefore remained a One Nation senator in the eyes of the Senate. It was also unclear whether Hanson intended to expel Anning solely from the [[parliamentary group]] or the wider organisational party as well.{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Rosie|title=Fraser Anning still sitting as a One Nation senator|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/fraser-anning-still-sitting-as-a-one-nation-senator/news-story/02fb94649cb95f7535064c0182f8efad|accessdate=17 November 2017|work=The Australian|date=16 November 2017}} On 15 January 2018, Anning advised the [[President of the Senate (Australia)|Senate President]] that he would henceforth sit as an independent.{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/senator-confirms-split-with-one-nation|title=Senator confirms split with One Nation|website=sbs.com.au|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180115192758/https://www.sbs.com.au/news/senator-confirms-split-with-one-nation|archivedate=2018-01-15|df=}} On 5 February 2018, he formed a voting bloc with Bernardi and Leyonhjelm.{{cite web|url=https://www.9news.com.au/national/2018/02/05/18/03/cory-bernardi-forms-right-wing-alliance-in-the-senate|title=Cory Bernardi forms right-wing alliance with David Leyonhjelm and Fraser Anning|website=9news.com.au|accessdate=24 April 2018|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180320041031/https://www.9news.com.au/national/2018/02/05/18/03/cory-bernardi-forms-right-wing-alliance-in-the-senate|archivedate=20 March 2018|df=}} He is a public opponent of [[same sex marriage]], and was one of twelve senators who voted against the 2017 bill.{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/gay-marriage/samesex-marriage-bill-set-to-pass-the-senate/news-story/77e3a18b6f990ee542a96d9e75ff0c5d |title=Senate passes same-sex marriage bill |newspaper=News.com.au |publisher=News Limited |date=29 November 2017 |accessdate=9 January 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180110054811/http://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/gay-marriage/samesex-marriage-bill-set-to-pass-the-senate/news-story/77e3a18b6f990ee542a96d9e75ff0c5d |archivedate=10 January 2018 |df= }} In 2017, when [[Cory Bernardi]] moved a motion opposing [[Medicare (Australia)|Medicare]] funding of gender-selective abortion, Anning was one of ten MPs who voted for the motion, which was defeated with 36 votes against.{{cite web|url=https://theyvoteforyou.org.au/divisions/senate/2017-11-16/2|title=Australian Senate vote not passed, 16th Nov 2017, 12:15 PM|website=They Vote For You|accessdate=24 April 2018|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305055242/https://theyvoteforyou.org.au/divisions/senate/2017-11-16/2|archivedate=5 March 2018|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-11-16/bernardi-making-provocative-motions-hanson-young-fires-up/9158076|title=From croissants to communism: Bernardi uses Senate motions to make ideological points|date=16 November 2017|website=Abc.net.au|accessdate=24 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171208205544/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-11-16/bernardi-making-provocative-motions-hanson-young-fires-up/9158076|archivedate=8 December 2017|df=}} On 22 March 2018, Anning announced that he would support the Turnbull Government's proposed company tax cuts.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-03-22/pauline-hanson-strikes-deal-on-company-tax-cuts/9576930|title=One Nation to back company tax cuts in exchange for funding for 1,000 apprentices|date=22 March 2018|website=Abc.net.au|accessdate=24 April 2018|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322111412/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-03-22/pauline-hanson-strikes-deal-on-company-tax-cuts/9576930|archivedate=22 March 2018|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-03-23/bradbury-senate-government-corporate-tax-rate/9579024|title=How a 'small army of Bradburys' could hand Turnbull a company tax cut|date=23 March 2018|website=Abc.net.au|accessdate=24 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180423235003/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-03-23/bradbury-senate-government-corporate-tax-rate/9579024|archivedate=23 April 2018|df=}} On 4 June 2018, Anning joined [[Katter's Australian Party]], becoming the party's first senator;{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-06-04/former-one-nation-senator-fraser-anning-joins-bob-katters-aust/9832986|title=Former One Nation senator joins Katter's party, predicts messy end for Hanson's Senate bloc|date=2018-06-04|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-AU|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180604114838/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-06-04/former-one-nation-senator-fraser-anning-joins-bob-katters-aust/9832986|archivedate=2018-06-04|df=}} however, he was expelled in October 2018 for his inflammatory rhetoric concerning immigration, including his mention of a "final solution" to the problem.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/oct/25/australian-senator-who-called-for-final-solution-to-immigration-expelled-from-party|title=Australian senator who called for 'final solution' to immigration expelled from party|last=Karp|first=Paul|date=25 October 2018|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=26 October 2018}} Anning introduced a private members' bill calling for less stringent import laws for mace, pepper spray and tasers, to "allow women to defend themselves". It was supported by [[David Leyonhjelm]], [[Peter Georgiou]], [[Cory Bernardi]] and [[Brian Burston]], but rejected by both major parties and the Greens.{{cite news |author1=AAP |title=Leyonhjelm tells senator to 'stop shagging men' during women's safety debate |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/jun/28/david-leyonhjelm-sarah-hanson-young-senator-stop-shagging-men-womens-safety-debate |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=the Guardian |date=28 June 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180704215048/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/jun/28/david-leyonhjelm-sarah-hanson-young-senator-stop-shagging-men-womens-safety-debate |archive-date=2018-07-04 |dead-url=no |df= }} == Controversy == ===Maiden speech=== On 14 August 2018, Anning delivered his maiden speech to the Senate in what was described by journalist Michael Koziol as "the most inflammatory maiden speech to an Australian Parliament since One Nation leader [[Pauline Hanson]]'s in 1996."{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/senator-honours-white-australia-policy-in-first-speech-and-calls-for-final-solution-on-immigration-20180814-p4zxhr.html|title=Senator honours White Australia Policy in first speech and calls for 'final solution' on immigration|last=Koziol|first=Michael|date=2018-08-14|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-08-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180814104902/https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/senator-honours-white-australia-policy-in-first-speech-and-calls-for-final-solution-on-immigration-20180814-p4zxhr.html|archive-date=2018-08-14|dead-url=no|df=}} In it, he called for a [[plebiscite]] to reintroduce [[White Australia Policy|racial and religious discrimination in immigration policy]], especially with regard to excluding Muslims. He criticised "cultural Marxism", "safe schools and gender fluidity garbage" and the "abuse" of the [[external affairs power]] of the [[Australian constitution]]. He also spoke in support of the right of civilians to own firearms, and the [[Bradfield Scheme]] irrigation proposal.{{Cite web|url=http://parlview.aph.gov.au/mediaPlayer.php?videoID=410935|title=Senate [Part 1] - 14/08/2018 11:54:59 – Parliament of Australia|website=parlview.aph.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-08-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180814232558/http://parlview.aph.gov.au/mediaPlayer.php?videoID=410935|archive-date=2018-08-14|dead-url=no|df=}} His most controversial comment included a reference to a "[[final solution]]", a term infamously used by the [[Nazi Party]] during preparation and execution of [[the Holocaust]] during [[World War II]].{{cite web |url=https://www.news.com.au/national/politics/while-all-muslims-are-not-terrorists-certainly-all-terrorists-these-days-are-muslims-senator-anning-said/news-story/c0753644cfccdda0394619e6f9dc01b5 |title=‘While all Muslims are not terrorists, certainly all terrorists these days are Muslims,’ Senator Anning said |work=News.com.au |date=15 August 2018 |accessdate=15 August 2018 |first=Ben |last=Graham |first2=Malcolm |last2=Farr |publisher=news.com.au |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180814202448/https://www.news.com.au/national/politics/while-all-muslims-are-not-terrorists-certainly-all-terrorists-these-days-are-muslims-senator-anning-said/news-story/c0753644cfccdda0394619e6f9dc01b5 |archive-date=2018-08-14 |dead-url=no |df= }} Anning has claimed his comments were taken out of context, saying that he had used the phrase to introduce the last of six policies he proposed about immigration. His comments received condemnation from across parliament, including the [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]], the [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberals]], the [[National Party of Australia|Nationals]], the [[Australian Greens|Greens]], [[Pauline Hanson's One Nation|One Nation]] and the [[Centre Alliance]], among other crossbenchers in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. He has refused to apologise for his comments.{{cite web |url=https://www.news.com.au/national/politics/why-the-term-final-solution-sparked-such-a-fierce-backlash/news-story/21d4eab87112e5bebf194dcd4a03b8d4 |title=Why the term ‘Final Solution’ sparked such a fierce backlash |first=Gavin |last=Fernando |publisher=News.com.au |date=15 August 2018 |accessdate=15 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180815033802/https://www.news.com.au/national/politics/why-the-term-final-solution-sparked-such-a-fierce-backlash/news-story/21d4eab87112e5bebf194dcd4a03b8d4 |archive-date=2018-08-15 |dead-url=no |df= }} Pauline Hanson said she was appalled by Anning's comments and described them as "straight from [[Joseph Goebbels|Goebbels]]' handbook".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/aug/15/fraser-anning-speech-straight-from-goebbels-handbook-says-pauline-hanson|title=Fraser Anning speech 'straight from Goebbels' handbook', says Pauline Hanson|publisher=''[[The Guardian Australia]]''|date=15 August 2018|access-date=15 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180815024829/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/aug/15/fraser-anning-speech-straight-from-goebbels-handbook-says-pauline-hanson|archive-date=2018-08-15|dead-url=no|df=}} However, Anning's party leader [[Bob Katter]] described it as "a magnificent speech, solid gold" and said he "1000 percent supports" Anning.{{cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/bob-katter-defends-magnificent-anning-speech-despite-criticism|title=Bob Katter defends 'magnificent' Anning speech despite criticism|publisher=SBS News|date=15 August 2018|access-date=15 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180815074230/https://www.sbs.com.au/news/bob-katter-defends-magnificent-anning-speech-despite-criticism|archive-date=2018-08-15|dead-url=no|df=}} In October of the same year, Katter expelled Anning.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/oct/25/australian-senator-who-called-for-final-solution-to-immigration-expelled-from-party|title=Australian senator who called for 'final solution' to immigration expelled from party|last=Karp|first=Paul|date=25 October 2018|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=26 October 2018}} === Opinions on LGBT === In September 2018 he called the [[Safe Schools Coalition Australia|Safe Schools programme]] "disgusting garbage" and said: “Fifty years ago, if a communist pervert had proposed that our nation’s children be forced to listen to sexually deviant propaganda, they would probably have been strung up[...]In critical theory, ethnic and religious minorities, radical feminists, sexual deviants, Third World immigrants and antisocial criminals could take the place of the proletariat to create a post-communist revolution, deconstructing traditional values and the white family[...]The ridiculous lie that gender is variable or fluid would be laughable if its intent were not so sinister". After his time in the Senate was up, Anning went on to post more on Twitter, writing, “The real goal of the Safe Schools Commo perverts is absolutely nothing to do with safety in schools or compassion. Safe schools is a dangerous and degenerate program.” {{Cite news|url=https://www.qnews.com.au/grow-up-senator-fraser-anning-slammed-for-homophobic-rant-in-the-senate/|title=Senator Fraser Anning Slammed For Homophobic Rant {{!}} QNews Magazine|last=|first=|work=QNews Magazine|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180920150112/https://www.qnews.com.au/grow-up-senator-fraser-anning-slammed-for-homophobic-rant-in-the-senate/|archive-date=2018-09-20|dead-url=no|df=}} === Facebook === In September 2018, Anning's Facebook page was "unpublished" (removed), after one of his posts was reported for hate speech. In a tweet, Anning said "Free speech is under attack [...] this is completely unacceptable and we will fight this."{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-28/fraser-annings-facebook-page-taken-down/10317638|title=Fraser Anning's public Facebook page removed for reported hate speech|publisher=ABC News|date=28 September 2018|access-date=28 September 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180928140307/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-28/fraser-annings-facebook-page-taken-down/10317638|archive-date=2018-09-28|dead-url=no|df=}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/queensland-senator-fraser-anning-banned-from-facebook/news-story/a8fb6b58dc4436a11f46470955eae11f|title=Queensland senator Fraser Anning banned from Facebook|publisher=''[[The Australian]]''|date=28 September 2018|access-date=28 September 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Current Senate crossbench}} {{Australian Senators}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Anning, Fraser}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:One Nation members of the Parliament of Australia]] [[Category:Members of the Australian Senate]] [[Category:Members of the Australian Senate for Queensland]] [[Category:Independent members of the Parliament of Australia]] [[Category:Australian white nationalists]] [[Category:Critics of Marxism]] [[Category:Critics of Islam]] [[Category:Opposition to same-sex marriage]] [[Category:Racism in Australia]]

{{BLP sources|date=January 2018}} {{notability|Biographies|date=January 2018}} '''Jacqueline Salit''' is a leader of the [[Independent voting movement]] in the [[United States]] and president of IndependentVoting.org and the Committee for a Unified Independent Party (CUIP).
As head of the Independent voting movement, Salit has asserted that Independents should not attach themselves to any other political party, but should remain 'anti-party', "whose ascension will be the death of established parties". Furthermore, she has highlighted the importance of remaining ideologically-neutral, or all-inclusive, maintaining that the goal is to wrest control of the electorate from established [[Two-party system|mainstream parties]], and promoting "cross-ideological" democracy.<ref>White, Micah; Occupy and Black Lives Matter failed. We can either win wars or win elections; The Guardian; August 28, 2017; https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/aug/29/why-are-our-protests-failing-and-how-can-we-achieve-social-change-today </ref>
Salit published a book titled ''Independents Rising'' in 2012.<ref>Essif, Amien; After Defeating Democrats, Will Ohio Unionists Form a New Labor Party?;In These Times; October 8, 2014; http://inthesetimes.com/working/entry/17227/defeat_democrats_independent_labor_party_ohio_lorain_county_unionists </ref>
She previously served as campaign manager for [[Lenora Fulani]]'s bid for the presidency.<ref>White, Micah; Occupy and Black Lives Matter failed. We can either win wars or win elections; The Guardian; August 28, 2017; https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/aug/29/why-are-our-protests-failing-and-how-can-we-achieve-social-change-today </ref>
==References== <references />

{{peacock|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox economist | name = James Hathaway | school_tradition = refugee law | image = | birth_date = 1956 | birth_place = Canada | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American, Canadian | alma_mater = [[York University]] (LL.B. hons.), [[Columbia University]] (J.S.D., LL.M.) </small> | field = [[refugee law]] | institution = [[University of Michigan]] | contributions = | module = {{Infobox person |child=yes | <!-- etc. --> | residence = [[United States]] }}
}} '''James Hathaway''' (born 1956) is an American-Canadian scholar of international [[refugee law]] and related aspects of human rights and public international law. His work is regularly cited by the most senior courts of the common law world, and has played a pivotal role in the evolution of refugee studies scholarship [http://www.oxfordjournals.org/our_journals/refuge/editorial_board.html]. Among his more critical achievements, Hathaway pioneered the now well-accepted understanding of refugee status as surrogate or substitute protection of human rights ([http://www.cambridge.org/us/academic/subjects/law/human-rights/law-refugee-status-2nd-edition The Law of Refugee Status], 2014); he authored the world's first comprehensive analysis of the human rights of refugees, merging doctrinal study of refugee and human rights law with empirical analysis of the state of refugee protection around the world ([http://www.cambridge.org/us/academic/subjects/law/human-rights/rights-refugees-under-international-law The Rights of Refugees under International Law], 2005); and he directed a multidisciplinary and global team of scholars and officials in an initiative to reconceive the structures of refugee protection more fairly to share burdens and responsibilities ([http://www.brill.com/reconceiving-international-refugee-law Reconceiving International Refugee Law], 1997).
==Background== Hathaway earned an LL.B. (Honors) at [[Osgoode Hall Law School]] of [[York University]], and a J.S.D. and LL.M. at [[Columbia University]]. He was called to the bars of the Canadian provinces of Ontario and New Brunswick. He presently resides in San Francisco, Tucson, and Vancouver.
Since 1998, Hathaway has been the [http://cgi2.www.law.umich.edu/_FacultyBioPage/facultybiopagenew.asp?uniqname=jch James E. and Sarah A Degan Professor of Law] at the [[University of Michigan Law School]] (USA) where he is also the founding Director of the [http://www.law.umich.edu/centersandprograms/refugeeandasylumlaw/Pages/default.aspx Program in Refugee and Asylum Law]. In addition he presently serves as: * [http://www.jur.uva.nl/news/newslist.cfm/4AA7D35A-885F-4489-B86649C9EDD96AAF Distinguished Visiting Professor of International Refugee Law] at the [[University of Amsterdam]] * Founding Patron and Senior Advisor of the non-governmental group [http://www.asylumaccess.org Asylum Access] * Emeritus Counsel on International Protection to the [http://www.refugees.org U.S. Committee for Refugees and Immigrants].
He has been appointed a visiting professor at the [[American University in Cairo]], and at the Universities of [[University of california|California]], [[University of Macerata|Macerata]], [[University of san francisco|San Francisco]], [[Stanford University|Stanford]], [[University of Tokyo|Tokyo]], and [[University of toronto|Toronto]].
Prior to joining the Michigan faculty, Hathaway served as: *Founding faculty member of the [https://www.umoncton.ca/umcm-droit/ Ecole de droit de l'Universite de Moncton] (Canada)(1981-1984), the world's first French-language common law program of study. *Professor of Law and Associate Dean of York University's [[Osgoode Hall Law School]] (1984-1998).
From 2008 until 2010, Hathaway was on leave from Michigan Law School as the Dean and William Hearn Chair of Law at the [[Melbourne Law School]] in Australia [http://www.justinian.com.au/1063-article]. At Melbourne he led the Law School's transition to become Australia's first, all-graduate (JD) program.<ref>Hathaway, J. 2009. [http://www.ialsnet.org/meetings/role/papers/HathawayJames%28Australia%29.pdf The Dean as Drudge]. [[International Association of Law Schools]] conference, Canberra, July. Professor Hathaway left to return to Michigan after voicing concerns that the traditional "Dean-as-scholar" model is not viable (Hathaway 2009), especially without the support of a high-level professional administrative team of the kind common in leading North American law schools. Upon his departure, Melbourne University Vice-Chancellor [[Glyn Davis]] wrote, "with Jim Hathaway's departure from the position of Law Dean, the University of Melbourne loses one of its most creative academic leaders. Professor Hathaway joined us at the start of 2008 to lead the most ambitious change in the history of Australian legal education – the establishment of this country's first all-graduate law program, flagship of the University's 'Melbourne Model' transition. Drawing on extensive experience as a faculty member and administrator at leading law schools in Canada and the United States, he led a seamless and wholly successful transition to the graduate education model. The Melbourne JD is now widely regarded as Australia's premier legal credential, attracting extraordinarily gifted students from across the country and around the world."</ref> Hathaway's main focus was to establish Melbourne as Australia's leading law school, including by joining leading law schools from around the world in establishing the London-based [[Center for Transnational Legal Studies|Centre for Transnational Legal Studies]], and launching joint degree programs linking Melbourne with leading law schools on three continents, including the Chinese University of Hong Kong (JD/LLM), New York University (JD/JD and JD/LLM) and Oxford University (JD/BCL).
==Scholarship== Hathaway's scholarly work focuses on international human rights and refugees.
Among his more important publications are a treatise on the [[refugee]] definition, [http://www.cambridge.org/us/academic/subjects/law/human-rights/law-refugee-status-2nd-edition?format=PB ''The Law of Refugee Status: 2nd Edition (with M. Foster)'' (2014)]; an interdisciplinary study of refugee law reform, ''Reconceiving International Refugee Law'' (1997); and an analysis of the nature of the legal duty to protect refugees [http://www.cambridge.org/uk/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521834940 ''The Rights of Refugees under International Law'' (2005)].

{{About|health researcher|English golfer|Jonathan Lomas}} '''Jonathan Lomas''' (born June 21, 1952 in [[Swansea, Wales]]) is a British-Canadian health researcher and the inaugural [[Chief Executive Officer]] of the [[Canadian Health Services Research Foundation]] (CHSRF). He specializes in health services research and knowledge translation/exchange and has been called the "godfather of knowledge translation" by the Canadian Institutes for Health Research. Lomas became an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]] in 2010.
==Early life and education== Lomas was born on June 21, 1952 in Swansea, Wales, but spent most of his childhood in England. He obtained an undergraduate degree in experimental psychology from Oxford University in the early 1970s before moving to Canada as a Commonwealth Scholar.<ref>Academy Health, [http://wwwold.academyhealth.org/about/lomas.htm ''2005 Board of Directors'']{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He obtained a master's degree in Psychology from the [[University of Western Ontario]] in 1975.<ref name="alumni">University of Western Ontario, [http://www.alumni.uwo.ca/connect/notable-alumni/jonathan-lomas.html ''Notable Alumni''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120906081546/http://www.alumni.uwo.ca/connect/notable-alumni/jonathan-lomas.html |date=2012-09-06 }}</ref>
==Career== Between 1982 and 1997 Lomas was a Professor of Health Policy Analysis in the Department of Clinical Epidemiology and Biostatistics at [[McMaster University]] where, along with [[Greg Stoddart]], he co-founded the [[Centre for Health Economics and Policy Analysis]] (CHEPA), an applied research group with a strong emphasis on research dissemination and uptake.<ref>Cohen, Lynne. "Health-policy research becoming a growth industry in Canada." ''Canadian Medical Association Journal'' (1992) 146(1):64-6.</ref>
In 1997 he became the inaugural CEO of the Canadian Health Services Research Foundation (CHSRF), a nationally endowed organization founded to improve the relevance and use of health services research in health system decision-making.<ref>[http://www.chsrf.ca/PublicationsAndResources/PastSeries/Links/Volume1Number1.aspx Canadian Health Services Research Foundation (CHSRF)]</ref>
Lomas has been a consultant to national and provincial governments in Canada, and also to non-governmental organizations, task forces and inquiries. He has worked on international health issues as a consultant for the [[World Health Organization]], the [[World Bank]], the [[International Development Research Centre]] and the [[Rockefeller Foundation]] in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, The Philippines, South Korea, Myanmar (Burma), Thailand and Australia. He has been a Visiting Professor or Scientist at the [[University of Gadjah Mada]] in [[Indonesia]] (1990), the [[University of Sydney]], [[Australia]] (where he was also a Visiting Scholar in the Department of Health of the [[New South Wales Government]]) (1996/97), and the Dutch national research and development agency ZonMw (2004).<ref>Ottawa Health Research Institute, [https://decisionaid.ohri.ca/isdm2005/bio-lomas.html ''3rd International Shared Decision Making Conference 2005''], June 14–16, 2005</ref>
Lomas has published two books.<ref>Lomas, Jonathan and Greg Stoddart. ''Planning or simply supply projections? : a critical review of physician manpower forecasting in Canada'', Hamilton, Ont.: Program for Quantitative Studies in Economics and Population, Faculty of Social Sciences, McMaster University, 1982</ref><ref>Lomas, Jonathan, ''First and foremost in community health centres : the centre in Sault Ste Marie and the CHC alternative'', Buffalo: University of Toronto Press, 1985.</ref> He has also published many peer reviewed articles and book chapters in the area of health policy and health services research.<ref>Selected list of articles: [http://www.labome.org/expert/canada/lomas/jonathan-lomas-1303790.html Labome.org]</ref> He is recognized as an international leader for his work exploring the role and impact of research evidence in health systems decision-making and is seen in Canada as the "godfather of knowledge translation."<ref name="alumni" />
Lomas received an Honorary Doctorate from the [[University of Montreal]] in 2005 as part of the Department of Health Administration’s 50th Anniversary celebrations.<ref>[http://www.adasum.com/default.aspx?page=25 ADASUM] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512064009/http://www.adasum.com/default.aspx?page=25 |date=2012-05-12 }}</ref> The Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) also recognized his achievements by establishing the ''Jonathan Lomas KT Doctoral Research Award'' Supplement in his honour.<ref>[http://www.cihr.ca/e/44896.html Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR)] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130115124621/http://www.cihr.ca/e/44896.html |date=2013-01-15 }}</ref> In 2006 he was elected as a Fellow of the [[Canadian Academy of Health Sciences]] (CAHS)<ref>[http://www.cahs-acss.ca/jonathan-lomas/ Canadian Academy of Health Sciences (CAHS)]</ref> and as a Specially Elected Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Canada]].<ref>Fields, University of Toronto, [http://www.fields.utoronto.ca/programs/scientific/06-07/FRSC/ ''Symposium Celebrating New Fellows of the Royal Society of Canada''], February 26, 2007</ref>
Dr. Lomas became an Officer of the Order of Canada in January 2010;<ref>The Governor General of Canada, [http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=13469 ''Order of Canada-Appointments'']</ref> In 2012 he was awarded the [[Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal]] .<ref>[http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=14019&lan=eng Governor General of Canada]</ref>
==Personal life==
Jonathan Lomas is now retired and lives in Victoria, British Columbia with his wife B.J. Porter.<ref>[http://www.health-policy-systems.com/content/6/1/1 Health Research Policy and Systems]</ref>
In 1980, he ran as a [[New Democratic Party]] candidate in the Canadian federal election in Toronto’s Don Valley West riding. He placed third, with 9.6% of the popular vote.<ref>Wikipedia, ''[[Don Valley West]]''</ref>

{{labor|sp=uk}} In [[British politics]], the term '''affiliated trade union''' refers to a [[trade union]] that has an ''affiliation'' to the British [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]. The party was created by the trade unions and [[socialist societies]] in 1900 as the [[British Labour Party#Labour Representation Committee|Labour Representation Committee]]. Since then, the unions have retained close institutional links with the Party. During [[Tony Blair]]'s [[New Labour|leadership of the Labour Party]] the [[National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers|RMT]] and [[Fire Brigades Union]] severed their links. However, the Fire Brigades Union re-affiliated to the Labour Party in November 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fbu.org.uk/news/2015/11/fbu-in-historic-affiliation-to-labour/|title=FBU in historic affiliation to Labour {{!}} Fire Brigades Union|website=www.fbu.org.uk|access-date=2016-10-05}}</ref>
The nature of affiliation means that the unions pay an annual fee to the Labour Party; in return, they and their members receive the privileges of affiliated membership. Unions select twelve of the thirty-two members of the Labour [[National Executive Committee]] and elect fifty per cent of the delegates to [[Labour Party Conference]]. In many cases, local union branches also affiliate to [[Constituency Labour Parties]] and their members who are also individual members of the Party may represent the Union as delegates on Labour Party structures.
Members of the unions may ''opt out'' of the affiliation, so that the member is not allowed to take part in any Labour Party ballots (such as the leadership election) in which other members of the affiliated union are involved.
Since 1994, affiliated trade unions have organised themselves into [[TULO - The Trade Union & Labour Party Liaison Organisation]], with a small number of staff to manage the relationship between the unions and the Party. A national TULO committee, with the unions' general secretaries, the Party Leader and Deputy Leader, [[General Secretary of the Labour Party|General Secretary]] and NEC Chair and MPs' representatives, meets regularly to co-ordinate work and policy.
==Affiliated unions== As of April 2017, the trade unions affiliated to the Labour Party are:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unionstogether.org.uk/about#unions|title=Unions Together|website=www.unionstogether.org.uk|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref>
*[[Associated Society of Locomotive Engineers and Firemen]] (ASLEF) *[[Bakers, Food and Allied Workers Union]] (BFAWU) *[[Community (trade union)|Community]] (formerly KFAT & ISTC) *[[Communication Workers Union (UK)|Communication Workers Union]] (CWU) *[[Fire Brigades Union]] (FBU) *[[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] *[[Musicians' Union (UK)|Musicians Union]] (MU) *[[National Union of Mineworkers (Great Britain)|National Union of Mineworkers]] (NUM) *[[Transport Salaried Staffs' Association]] (TSSA) *[[UNISON]] (The Public Services Union) *[[Unite the Union|Unite]] (general workers in public and private sectors) *[[Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers]] (USDAW)
The [[General Federation of Trade Unions (UK)|General Federation of Trade Unions]] (GFTU) represents its members, seven of the smaller unions, on many of the committees if they cannot send a delegate. In 2015, [[Unity (trade union)|Unity]] merged into the GMB. In January 2017, the [[Broadcasting, Entertainment, Cinematograph and Theatre Union]] (BECTU) merged with [[Prospect (trade union)|Prospect]], a trade union that represents certain grades in the [[civil service]] and other professionals. Because Prospect represents civil servants, they are politically neutral and so BECTU disaffiliated from the Labour Party as a condition of the merger. In January 2017, the [[Union of Construction, Allied Trades and Technicians]] (UCATT) merged into Unite.
==Former affiliates== Formerly, there were many more small trade unions in the UK, and many of them affiliated to the Labour Party. In 1946, the affiliates were:<ref>[[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]], ''Report of the Forty-Fifth Annual Conference of the Labour Party'', pp.73-78</ref>

'''Leon Mercer Jordan''' (May 6, 1905, [[Kansas City, Missouri]] - July 15, 1970, Kansas City, Missouri) was an American police officer, politician and civil rights leader who was assassinated.<ref name=Unsolved>{{cite web|title=Unsolved killing of Leon Jordan echoes civil rights era|publisher=[[Kansas City Star]]|author=Mike McGraw and Glenn E. Rice|date=2010-09-09|accessdate=2012-02-18 |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2010/09/09/2210688/unsolved-killing-echoes-civil.html}}</ref><ref name=AP>{{cite web|title=3 Gunmen sought in Killing of Missouri Lawmaker|publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=1970-07-15|accessdate=2012-02-18 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=V-U0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=R4cFAAAAIBAJ&pg=825,3027791&hl=en}} {{dead link|date=November 2017}}</ref> He was "one of the most influential African Americans in Kansas City's history"<ref name=Dictionary>{{cite book | last = Christensen | first = Lawrence O. | title = Dictionary of Missouri biography | publisher = [[University of Missouri Press]] | year = 1999 | page = 445 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6gyxWHRLAWgC&pg=PA445&dq=%22Leon+Jordan%22+Liberia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=C5JBT83JEoONigKm_uSJAQ&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Leon%20Jordan%22%20Liberia&f=false | isbn = 978-0-8262-1222-1}}</ref> and, at the time of his death, the "state's most powerful black politician".<ref name=Unsolved/>
==Early years== [[File:LeonJordan Memorial (5).jpg|thumb|left|Statue at Leon M. Jordan Memorial Park in [[Kansas City, Missouri]]. The park and statue were dedicated on May 17, 1975.]]Jordan attended [[Lincoln College Preparatory Academy|Lincoln High School]] in Kansas City, served in the U.S. Army,<ref name=Dictionary/> and graduated from [[Wilberforce University]] in [[Wilberforce, Ohio]] in 1932.<ref name=Vote/>{{dead link|date=November 2017}} He married fellow Wilberforce student [[Orchid I. Jordan|Orchid Irene Ramsey]]<ref name=Orchid>{{cite web|title=Orchid Jordan, former legislator, dead at age 85: Widow of Freedom Inc. co-founder served 16 years in the House. |publisher=[[Kansas City Star]] |date=1995-12-27|accessdate=2012-02-18 |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=KC&p_theme=kc&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF42614A61F1CE&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM}}</ref><ref name=Library>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Leon M. Jordan Collection: Biographical Sketch | work = University Libraries: LaBudde Special Collections Dept. | publisher = [[University of Missouri - Kansas City]] | url = http://library.umkc.edu/spec-col-collections/jordan | format = | doi = | accessdate = February 19, 2012}}</ref> on August 10, 1932.<ref name=Vote/> After graduation, he worked as a school teacher.<ref name=AP/>
Jordan joined the [[Kansas City Police Department]] in 1938, became a detective, and in 1952, became the first African-American police lieutenant in that department's history. He took a leave of absence in 1947, and spent eight years training the police forces of [[Liberia]].<ref name=Library/> A pilot, he flew his own plane around the country.<ref name=Dictionary/> In 1948, he helped coordinate the rescue of the French High Commissioner of West Africa and 16 other French officials after their plane made a forced landing. He was awarded the Chevalier of the Star of Africa by Liberian President [[William Tubman]] in 1948.<ref name=Vote/>
In 1951, Jordan became a life member of the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]].<ref name=Vote/> He returned to Kansas City in February, 1952, and was promoted to police lieutenant. However, he discovered that he had little power, so he resigned and went back to Liberia for three years.<ref name=Dictionary/> He returned to Kansas City for good in the mid-1950s, and purchased the Green Duck Tavern.<ref name=Dictionary/>
==Civil rights and politics==
In 1958, Jordan became a Democratic Party committeeman for the 14th Ward of Kansas City.<ref name=Dictionary/> In 1962, Jordan co-founded [[Freedom, Inc.]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Filmmaker Emiel Cleaver tells the story of Freedom Inc.|publisher=[[Kansas City Star]] |date=2012-02-17|accessdate=2012-02-18 |url= http://www.kansascity.com/2012/02/17/3428881/star-magazine-interview-filmmaker.html}} {{dead link|date=November 2017}}</ref> along with [[Bruce R. Watkins]].<ref name=Vote>[http://test.library.umkc.edu/sites/default/files/images/spec-col/col-jordan-finding-aid3.pdf "A Vote For Freedom: The Life of Leon Mercer Jordan"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} by Dr. [[Robert M. Farnsworth]], [[UMKC]] Professor Emeritus of English</ref> The organization advocated political awareness among African-Americans in Kansas City, organized a massive voter registration drive, and developed African-American political candidates. In 1963, Jordan and Watkins helped pass an accommodations ordinance, desegregating all public facilities in the city.<ref name=Library/>
In 1964, Freedom, Inc. put forward eight candidates for office, and seven of them won.<ref>{{cite book | last = Greene, | first = Lorenzo Johnston | authorlink = |author2=Gary R. Kremer |author3=Antonio Frederick Holland | title = Missouri's Black Heritage | publisher = [[University of Missouri Press]] | series = | volume = | edition = | year = 1993 | location = | pages = 218 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=G357gYrd_goC&pg=PA218&dq=%22Leon+Jordan%22+assassination&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jJxBT-O-FKSniAKlnoyLAQ&sqi=2&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Leon%20Jordan%22%20assassination&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8262-0905-4 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref> Among them was Jordan, who was elected to the first of three terms in the [[Missouri House of Representatives]].<ref>[http://s1.sos.mo.gov/archives/history/historicallistings/molegj Missouri General Assembly-Roster]</ref> He was campaigning for a fourth term at the time he was murdered. Shortly before his death, he described himself as a "radical", adding "I'm not a conformist but there are bounds of reason."<ref name=AP/>
==Assassination==
At about 1:00 a.m. on July 15, 1970, he was killed just outside his Green Duck Tavern by three shotgun blasts. Eyewitnesses reported that the three killers were African-American. The shotgun had been stolen, and was abandoned immediately. When it was recovered, it was traced to a burglary five years earlier in [[Independence, Missouri]].<ref name=mob>{{cite news | last = McGraw | first = Mike | author2 = Glenn E. Rice | title = '70s slaying of KC politician Leon Jordan a mob hit? | newspaper = [[Kansas City Star]] | location = [[Kansas City, Missouri]] | date = October 30, 2010 | url = http://www.kansascity.com/2010/10/30/2372174/70s-slaying-of-kc-politician-a.html | accessdate = February 19, 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101102223110/http://www.kansascity.com/2010/10/30/2372174/70s-slaying-of-kc-politician-a.html | archivedate = November 2, 2010 | df = }}</ref>
Three men were arrested for the murder, including at least one affiliated with a criminal group called the "Black Mafia". One man was acquitted, and charges were dropped against the other two suspects.<ref name=killing>{{cite news | last = McGraw | first = Mike | author2 = Glenn E. Rice | title = Evidence points to mob associate's involvement in Jordan killing | newspaper = [[Kansas City Star]] | location = [[Kansas City, Missouri]] | date = October 31, 2010 | url = http://www.kansascity.com/2010/10/31/2375644/evidence-points-to-mob-associates.html | accessdate = February 19, 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101104011447/http://www.kansascity.com/2010/10/31/2375644/evidence-points-to-mob-associates.html | archivedate = November 4, 2010 | df = }}</ref>
==Murder weapon==
Jordan was killed using a [[Remington Model 870#Variants|Remington 12-gauge Wingmaster shotgun]] which was one of several guns that had been stolen from a hardware store in [[Independence, Missouri]] in 1965.<ref name=gun>{{cite news | last = McGraw | first = Mike | title = The missing gun turns up — in use by the police | newspaper = [[Kansas City Star]] | location = [[Kansas City, Missouri]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 9, 2010 | url = http://www.kansascity.com/2010/09/09/2210698/the-missing-gun-turns-up-in-use.html | accessdate = February 19, 2012}}</ref> A January, 1966, report on the burglary by the Independence Police Department stated that the guns had later been sold through a "North End Italian fence." This report was not discovered in the initial investigation of Jordan's murder, but was uncovered by investigative journalists working for the ''Kansas City Star'' in 2010. When the reporters asked the Kansas City Police Department about the gun, they were told that it had been lost in 1973. The gun may have been sold in a police surplus auction. Some time later, the police purchased the used shotgun from a gun store, and did not check the serial number. The gun was refurbished and placed into police service.<ref name=mob/>
On November 5, 1997, a police officer used the shotgun to shoot and wound an armed suspect in [[North Kansas City, Missouri]]. The gun was analyzed by the crime lab, who failed to identify it as the Jordan murder weapon, and it was returned to police service the following year. Only when the ''Kansas City Star'' asked questions about the missing shotgun in 2010 did a crime lab technician run a computer check that located the gun, which was recovered from the trunk of a police car and then returned to the evidence room.<ref name=gun/>
==2010 investigation==
In 2010, reporters with the ''[[Kansas City Star]]'' began investigating the assassination while preparing for coverage of the 40th anniversary of Jordan's death. This led to discovery of the missing murder weapon and some old fingerprint cards, and that motivated the Kansas City Police Department to re-open the official investigation of the department's oldest cold case. Civil rights leader [[Alvin Sykes]] pressed the department for a complete investigation.<ref name=gun/> In trying to determine who was responsible for the assassination, the newspaper reported that Jordan and his Freedom, Inc. political movement had been opposed to the "North End" faction in Kansas City politics, a group under the influence of [[La Cosa Nostra]], and which had previously controlled black voting blocs. In 1965, Jordan had punched [[Frank Mazzuca (Missouri)|Frank Mazzuca]], a fellow state legislator who was alleged to have supported mob interests in [[Jefferson City, Missouri]], and death threats against Jordan were reported in the aftermath.<ref name=mob/>
The newspaper reported that police informants associated with the Black Mafia had described the killing as a favor to North End mob interests, and that it was organized by "Shotgun Joe" Centimano, owner of a local liquor store. The informants said that Centimano had supplied the murder weapon and recruited the killers. The newspaper reported that one informant said the assassination had elements of both a "[[contract killing]]" and a "revenge killing", and that another said it was "all about politics."<ref name=killing/> News coverage said that a 900-page police report finished in 2011 had concluded that mob boss [[Nicholas Civella|Nick Civella]] had given his "blessing" to Jordan's assassination.<ref>{{cite news | title = Police send report on 1970 slaying to prosecutor | newspaper = [[Columbia Missourian]] | location = [[Columbia, Missouri]] | date = February 9, 2011 | url = http://www.columbiamissourian.com/stories/2011/02/09/police-send-report-1970-slaying-prosecutor/ | accessdate = February 19, 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20120729210125/http://www.columbiamissourian.com/stories/2011/02/09/police-send-report-1970-slaying-prosecutor/ | archivedate = July 29, 2012 | df = }}</ref> No one was indicted because all of the main players were dead by then.
==Orchid Jordan== {{main|Orchid I. Jordan}} Jordan's widow, [[Orchid I. Jordan|Orchid]], became a candidate for his legislative seat when her husband was killed. She won the election, and served for 16 years in the Missouri House of Representatives.<ref name=Library/> She died on December 25, 1995 at the age of 85.<ref name=Orchid/>
==Legacy== [[File:LeonJordan Memorial (14).jpg|thumb| A statue and park memorializing Jordan was dedicated May 17, 1975. More recently, a plaque commemorating [[Freedom, Inc.]] was placed on the back of the statue's base.]] The Leon M. Jordan Memorial Park, located at 31st Street and Benton Boulevard in Kansas City, features a statue of Jordan and the following text on a plaque on the front of its base:
{{quote| THE LEADER
LEON MERCER JORDAN
1905-1970
Leon Mercer Jordan was a leader, a true and gifted servant of his people. He was born in Kansas City, Missouri, U.S.A. during an era when he was, solely by reason of his race and color, generally excluded from the society of other so-called civilized folk because of policies and practices of racial segregation, discrimination and exclusion which were firmly embedded in the laws of this land and were clothed with every legal sanction. Early in life he began to apply his vision, wisdom and iron will to a dissolution of the restraints which were imposed upon him and his people at the time of his birth. At the time of his death, every legal sanction for racial segregation and discrimination had been eradicated, and he had founded and forged into an instrument of tremendous political force and power an organization called [[Freedom, Inc.]], and through Freedom Inc., Leon Mercer Jordan accomplished the political liberation of black folk in this town and state, he was a Lieutenant of police, Chief of the Constabulary of the Republic of [[Liberia]], a member of the House of Representatives of Missouri, but he is remembered here by this mass of stone and bronze because he was "the Leader" whose work and efforts contributed significantly toward the realization of justice, equality and freedom, for all.}}
His papers, including extensive documentation of his service in Liberia, are collected in the library of the University of Missouri-Kansas City.<ref name=Library/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== Farnsworth, Robert M. (2013), [https://mospace.umsystem.edu/xmlui/bitstream/handle/10355/15690/farnleonjord.pdf?sequence=1 Leon Mercer Jordan, The Founder of Freedom, Inc. Following in the Footsteps of His Father and Grandfather], [[University of Missouri Press]]

{{for|the economic concept|Liquidationism (economics)}} {{Communism sidebar}}
In [[Leninist]] theory, '''liquidationism''' ({{lang-ru|Ликвидаторство}}) is the ideological abandonment ([[liquidation]]) of the [[vanguard party]]'s program, either in whole or in part, by party members. ==Concept== According to the [[Bolshevik]] leader [[Vladimir Lenin]], writing in 1909, liquidationism "consists ideologically in negation of the [[revolution]]ary [[class struggle]] of the [[socialist]] [[proletariat]] in general, and denial of the [[Dictatorship of the proletariat|hegemony of the proletariat]]".<ref name=liqu>{{cite web |url=http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1909/jul/11.htm |title=The Liquidation of Liquidationism|last=Lenin |first=Vladimir |author-link=Lenin |publisher= |date= |publication-date= 11 July 1909|website=Marxist Internet Archive|access-date=3 November 2018}}</ref>
[[Nikolai Aleksandrovich Rozhkov]] was identified by [[Lenin]] as a liquidationist.<ref name=liberal>{{cite web |url=https://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1911/lilapman/i.htm#v17pp74-313 |title=A Liberal Labour Party Manifesto|last=Lenin |first=Vladimir |author-link=Lenin |publisher= |date= |publication-date= 3 December 1911|website=Marxist Internet Archive|access-date=3 November 2018}}</ref>
In his concluding remarks to the 1914 ''Marxism and Liquidationism'' symposium, Lenin made the distinction between "Left liquidationism," which is "leaning towards [[anarchism]], and "Right liquidationism," which is "liquidationism proper" and "leans towards [[liberalism]]."<ref name=dist>{{cite web |url=http://www.marx2mao.com/Lenin/CRML14.html#fnp266 |title=Concluding remarks to the symposium Marxism and Liquidationism|last=Lenin |first=Vladimir |author-link=Lenin |publisher= |date= |publication-date= April 1914|website=From Marx to Mao|access-date=3 November 2018}}</ref> ==Current use== The term is still used in modern, ideological discussions of the Communist Left.<ref name=today>E.g. :{{cite web |url=http://www.bolshevik.org/statements/ibt_20170610_liquidationism.html |title=Liquidationism Yesterday and Today|last= Lichtenberg |first=Christoph |author-link= |publisher= |date=2 June 2017 |website=International Bolshevik Tendency|access-date=3 November 2018}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Vanguardism]] *[[Reformism]] *[[Bolshevism]] *[[Menshevism]] *[[Factions of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], which later split into Bolsheviks and Mensheviks
==References== <references/>
